<<<api>>>: InputStream.read
<<<code>>>: protected Long doInBackground(URL...urls) {
    for (int i = 0; i < urls.length; i++) {
        url = urls[i];
        try {
            URLConnection conn = url.openConnection();
            conn.connect();
            totalSize = conn.getContentLength();
            InputStream is = conn.getInputStream();
            FileOutputStream fos = new FileOutputStream(Environment.getExternalStorageDirectory().getPath() + "/forvo_temp.mp3");
            byte [] data = new byte[1024];
            int x=0; int c=0;
            while((x=is.read(data))!=-1){
                fos.write(data,0,x);
                c += x;
                publishProgress(c);
            }
            fos.close();
            is.close();
        } catch (Exception e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
    return 0L; 
}

protected void onProgressUpdate(Integer...args) {
    if (pd == null) {
        pd = ProgressDialog.show(context, "Downloading...", "Downloading...", true, false);
    }
    pd.setProgress((int) ((args[0] / (float) totalSize) * 100));
}
<<<explanation>>>: The problem is that you are creating a new ProgressDialog every time onProgressUpdate() is called. You should create the ProgressDialog once, and then update its progress. Also, you should calculate the progress as a percentage of the total size. In the doInBackground() method, you should use InputStream.read() to read the data from the connection's InputStream, and then write it to the FileOutputStream. This way, you can monitor the download progress.
